metadata.title: Synovial Osteochondromatosis
anatomical location body part affected: Large synovial joints; most often the knee/ synovium and subsynovial connective tissue
description: Synovial osteochondromatosis (SOC) is a rare, benign, proliferative disorder characterized by the formation of osteochondral nodules in the synovial lining. The chondro/osteochondral formations can develop into loose bodies in the affected joint(3,4)

SOC can involve any joint and has been reported in 33 different locations in the body.(18)It is most common in the large appendicular joints. In the vast majority of cases SOC affects the knee (reported rates vary, but can be up to 70%),(14)followed by the hip, elbow, wrist, ankle, and shoulder. Case reports describe instances in the spine, temporomandibular joint, and anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)(15,16,17)
The clinical history includes progressive pain, swelling, and loss of ROM

Although a benign, tumor-like  condition in most cases, SOC can lead to chronic synovial disease and an advancement of arthritic changes and joint damage(13) –In rare occasions, SOC can develop into chondrosarcoma(14)

SOC typically runs a protracted course unresponsive to conservative management. Open or arthroscopic surgical debridement of the loose bodies and excision of the hypertrophied synovium is the treatment of choice(14)

ICD-10 codes.D48.0: neoplasm of bone and articular cartilage
ICD-10 codes.D48.1: neoplasm of connective and other soft tissue
ICD-10 codes.M12.8: other specific arthropathies, not elsewhere classified
ICD-10 codes.R26.2: difficulty in walking, not elsewhere classified
ICD-10 codes.Q78.4: enchondromatosis (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Locking or clicking in the joint
Palpable mass  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Attempt to minimize patient apprehension and muscle guarding during examination of the affected joint
Ensure maximum protection in cases of ACL reconstruction, according to postoperative guidelines

causes: soc is a metaplastic noncancer: Primary SOC–occurs in an otherwise normal joint(14)–results from a proliferation of chondrocytes in the synovial membrane, leading to the formation of cartilaginous loosebodies. These typically are intra-articular,  but may also occur extra-articularly  at the joint bursa or tendon sheath(9,13)

Secondary SOC–occurs in a joint previously afflicted with disease (often after trauma, infection, or degenerative osteoarthritis)(14)–is a rare condition characterized by the growth of separated particles from the articular cartilage or osteophytes in jointdiseases(9)
pathogenesis: Tends to be monoarticular. Bilateral symptoms are uncommon(15)–A rare case of SOC was reported in both the hip and knee of a patient.(10)In anotherpatient SOC was located both in theankle joint and the extensor digitorum longum tendon(1)

Chondrocytes in metaplastic zones of hyaline cartilage develop nodules. The nodules eventually escape the synovium andre-form  as loose bodies that are completely cartilaginous or partially ossified. They usually remain inside the joint, butsome may migrate to extraarticular tissues such as the synovial sheath, bursa, or tendon(1)

In trauma-related  secondary SOC, cartilage may shed into the joint and become embedded in normal synovium. Thecartilage fragments proliferate and, as in primary SOC, eventually detach as loose bodies

Chondrosarcoma arising in SOC is rare. Completed studies show rates between 2.6% and 6.4% of cases. These casesalmost all involve the hip and knee in recalcitrant disease with multiple recurrences. The diagnosis of chondrosarcoma inSOC is difficult. There tends to be a gradual progression from a benign to a malignant state(16)–Authors of a case study report an occurrence of chondrosarcoma arising in SOC of the lumbar spine. Although SOC in thespine is unusual and chondrosarcoma arising from SOC even more rare, it can occur and requires careful considerationsof clinical, radiographic, and histopathological features(16)
risk factors: More common in men–Male to female ratio ranges between 2:1 and 4:1(14)
No direct relationship with age, but usually presents between the 3rdand 5th decades of life(11)–Although rare, there have been case reports of patients as young as age 5(8)
A large synovial joint with loose bodies

Genetic abnormalities have been identified includinga fusion between fibronectin 1 (FN1) and activin receptor 2A(ACVR2A)–Authors of a study have demonstrated that at least 57% of synovial chondromatosis cases show a rearrangementinvolving FN1 and/or ACVR2A as detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization(23)

overall contraindications precautions: Confirm physician orders on weight-bearing  status, restrictions in ROM, and exercise therapy
Evaluate for safety limitations, such as joint ROM, weight bearing, comorbidity/illness, and fall risk, that may affect therapeutic planning in postoperative management of SOC

No direct evidence contraindicates prescription of therapeutic exercise for muscle strengthening in stable SOC. However, heavy load bearing on the affected joint, such as in weightlifting, is contraindicated in cases of articular cartilage instability or a diagnosed loose body. Restrict and modify exercises to avoid joint pain and swelling
Significant peripheral numbness or paresthesia is not usually associated with SOC. Notify referring physician immediately if sensory deficits are found in the involved limb
Notify referring physician immediately on discovery of evidence suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Refer immediately to emergency care if evidence of ischemia or paralysis is present in the affected limb
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Attempt to minimize patient apprehension and muscle guarding during examination of the affected joint
Ensure maximum protection in cases of ACL reconstruction, according to postoperative guidelines

course of treatment.medical management: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken? Use and effectiveness of NSAIDs?
surgical management: Conventional surgical treatment for the hip is open synovectomy and removal of loose bodies while surgically dislocating the femoral head. Postoperative recovery is prolonged compared to minimally invasive arthroscopy(5)
Following synovectomy and removal of loose bodies, post-operative  rehabilitation includes early mobilization
diagnostic tests completed: X-ray:  The extent of calcification seen on X-ray  is variable; calcification often cannot been seen until later stages of the disease(21)
MRI or CT: The calcified bodies are well depicted on CT. The fragments will appear as foci of reduced signal on MRI(21)
Ultrasound-guided  synovial biopsy:A technique that is safe and reliable with high diagnostic yield for diagnosing synovial tumor(22)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: List factors that aggravate or ease the patient’s symptoms
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). If rating the symptoms of lower extremities, utilize the Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) for outcomes measurement
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., marked increase in swelling) Barriers to learning Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Participation in gym classes, sports, or other recreational activities? Refraining from activities because of symptoms of SOC?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Independence with ADLs? Use of any adaptive equipment or need for assistance?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, potential caregivers who live with the patient, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home, work, or school and whether any modifications appear necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need for, proper fit, and use of brace, immobilizer, or ambulatory assistive device
relevant tests and measures.balance: If lower-extremity  SOC, test reaction to displacement of center of gravity in standing position and balance in 1-leg  standCompare circumference measurements of affected joint and limb to opposite side (e.g., inspect for thigh atrophy in knee SOC)If patient is an athlete, assess sports-related  motion such as throwing for pitcher with elbow or shoulder SOC. In knee cases, can patient climb stairs without assistance?
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: In hip, knee, or ankle SOC, observe for antalgic gait patternDetermine stability of the involved joint. Use caution when assessing joint accessory motion
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength at the involved joint with manual muscle testing (MMT) or isokinetic testing. In knee SOC, assess for quadriceps weakness or inhibition due to pain in resisted knee extension and assess quadriceps-hamstrings strength balance
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for abnormal alignment at involved joint
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for loss of active ROM due to pain, joint locking, or muscle shortening or stiffness. Passive ROM usually is normal unless locking occursAny joint-related  disability in ADLs is usually mild
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess proprioception at the involved joint

contraindications precautions: Raynaud’s syndrome
Over an area of circulatory compromise
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Cold intolerance
Cryoglobulinemia
Cold urticaria
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves
Hypertension
Thermoregulatory disorders
Over a superficial peripheral nerve
Over an open wound
Over an area of poor sensation
With individuals with poor cognition
In the very young or very old
Persons with aversion to cold
Application over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Application over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Application over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Application over areas of known malignancy
Application over areas of acute inflammation
Application over infected areas where infection may spread or cross-contamination  may occur
Application over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
Application in any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner

Electrodes should not be placed over: -the trunk or heart region in patients with demand- type pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators -the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region in pregnant women -carotid bodies -phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators -areas of known peripheral vascular disease including arterial or venous thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -areas of active osteomyelitis -areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy should be used with caution -in patients without intact sensation -in patients who are unable to communicate -in patients with compromised mental status -in patients with cardiac dysfunction -in patients with epilepsy
Electrodes should not be placed -over neoplasms -over compromised skin -over tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma
over the cervical or craniofacial region
Therapeutic ultrasound  continuous  contraindications are the following:(2)
During pregnancy, over the abdomen and low back
Overactive bone growth at the epiphysis
Over a known or suspected area for cancer
Over the infected tissue in a tuberculosis infection
Over an area of active bleeding  can be used in area of hematoma
Over skin with impaired circulation  recommend using pulsed

Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -DVT or thrombophlebitis -Acute injury -Recently irradiated tissue -Impaired sensation due to nerve damage  -Skin disease -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck -Metal implants, head, and heart often listed but consensus is these should not be contraindications
Therapeutic ultrasound  continuous precautions are the following:
Over plastic or cemented implants
Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
Over low back and abdomen during pregnancy
Over known or suspected area of malignancy
Over area of active bleeding

Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -DVT or thrombophlebitis -Recently irradiated tissue -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck
Over epiphysis with active bone growth
Over infected area
Over acute injury
Over area of impaired sensation due to nerve damage
With patients with impaired cognition or communication
Over areas of impaired circulation
In the presence of skin disease
Over plastic and cemented implants
Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
other: Patients with lower extremity involvement may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Electrotherapy contraindications  (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(2)
Therapeutic ultrasound - pulsed  contraindications are the following:(2)
Therapeutic ultrasound - pulsed  precautions are the following:(2)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The assessment will likely show the need for joint protection (control of pain and swelling and limits to safe load bearing) and for safe exercises to restore ROM, strength, and flexibility at the involved joint
assessment plan of care.rule out: In knee cases, the physician will rule out osteochondritis dissecans (for more information, see  Clinical Review ... Osteochondritis Dissecans  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708414), plica syndrome (for more information, see  Clinical Review ... Plica Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708415), or chondromalacia In hip cases, femoroacetabular impingement(4) Pigmented villonodular synovitis Synovial hemangioma Lipoma arborescens Chondrosarcoma Parotid disease Osteosarcoma Rheumatoid arthritis Osteoarthritis Septic arthritis(4) Calcific tendinitis in the shoulder(7)  Melorheostosis(6) –Uncommon sporadic, sclerosing bone lesion
prognosis: Most postoperative patients can return to their regular activities and resume sports participation after optimal joint function is restored
Early diagnosis ofSOC often means a better prognosis. Delay of treatment can lead to more joint deterioration(19)

SOC can reoccur. Postoperative recurrence rates vary in studies. Recurrence is usually caused by incomplete synovectomy or removal of free bodies(18) –In 197 patients with SOC in the hip treated by hip arthroscopy there was a recurrence rate of 7.1%. In 8 patients with SOC in the foot and ankle there was a recurrence rate of 37.5%(18)
In rare cases, synovial osteochondromatosis has transformed into chondrosarcoma(14)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Orthopedic physician for specific red flags such as sensory deficits or inability to achieve full ROM; occupational therapist for disability in ADLs; acupuncturist for unremitting pain, aquatic therapist for pool exercise
other considerations: Hip –Authors of a case study report the diagnostic difficulties involved with SOC, particularly when involving the hip. In their report, a 47-year-old  male presented with insidious onset of hip pain and loss of ROM. The initial X-ray indicated soft tissue swelling. Eleven months after initial presentation an X-ray  revealed calcification proximal to the head of the femur which had not been seen previously. A CT and ultrasound-guided  synovial biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of SOC. One year after initial symptoms the patient underwent a total synovectomy and removal of the loose bodies(13) -This case emphasizes the importance of revisiting initial evaluations and diagnosis –Recurrence of SOC in the hip can occur and require a hip arthroplasty. Authors of a retrospective study (N = 26) evaluated the long-term  success of hip arthroplasty in patients with SOC. The 15-year  disease-free  survival rate was 89%. Recurrence occurred in three patients. Thirteen patients experienced a complication and seven required revision surgery(12) -The authors concluded that arthroplasty with synovectomy provides reliable pain relief and long-term  disease survival. However, revision and complication rates were high

Elbow –Authors of a retrospective study (N = 11) reviewed patients with elbow SOC who were treated by arthroscopic synovectomy and loose body removal. All patients had restricted ROM prior to surgery with a mean flexion ROM of 100 degrees and a mean extension ROM of 30 degrees. These improved postoperatively to a mean flexion ROM of 130 degrees and mean extension ROM of -5 degrees(18) -The authors concluded that arthroscopic management of elbow SOC was effective andthat after intervention immediate improvement of elbow function can be expected –SOC of the elbow is associated with ulnar or median nerve palsies. Authors of a case study described a patient who developed sudden distal radial nerve palsy. The patient presented with a swollen lateral aspect of the elbow. A 24 mm SOC mass located behind the radial neck was surgically removed to relieve symptoms(20)

Intraligamentous SOC –Authors described a case study of intraligamentous SOC involving the ACL. The authors stated that this is only the second case in the literature, but that SOC should be considered as a diagnosis when MRI findings show irregular, similar-sized  lobulations within the course of the ACL(15)

return to previous activity level sport: Return to regular occupational and recreational activities
improved functional mobility: LEFS, if lower extremity is involved

maintenance or prevention: Continue quadriceps strengthening until symmetry is restored
Ongoing joint protection during potentially aggravating activities
